posts.cooked:
Apologies if this has been covered before, I searched this forum but didn’t come up with anything mentioning “last seen”.

Basically as per the topic title… I would like to have some indication to know whether the current contact is still using Signal or hasn’t opened it in a long time (and so is likely to not be using it any more).
This will help in many situations, for example if a message is not being delivered, then judging from the ‘last seen’ data I could tell if my contact is temporarily offline (if they’ve been on Signal recently) or been off Signal for a while and maybe it’d be a good idea to contact them another way rather than wait for the Signal message to be delivered.

I know Signal don’t keep much data on their servers but as far as I remember they do keep the last date/week a user came online so if we could perhaps see that, it would be helpful.

Of course there can (or should) be a toggle in the settings to turn this on or off according to our privacy concerns.

link_counts.title: How can I determine if a user is online?
WhatsApp is working on the ability to hide the online status!
Add upvote system to the forum
Message Bubble and Chat view rework
Remove delivery indicators, they are problematic for privacy in multiple ways
Always-on (or group admin option to use) read receipts regardless of a group member's setting

posts.cooked:
If you send someone a Signal message, and the indicator shows, that the message is not delivered for several days… that could mean, that his Smartphone is turned off. Or that he does not use Signal anymore.
Normally I would give this person a call then. That is the easiest solution. And if you get a voice saying, the number is no longer registered, then you know, that he has a new phone number.

True. Although I’d say it’s much more convenient to be able to see the information up front rather than having to wait for a few days to see if a message is being delivered, or having to call someone on a regular insecure line.
And as you say, it might just mean their phone is turned off - or they are abroad for a holiday with no data connection.

posts.name: rocknjohn
posts.cooked: I’m an ‘ahhh hell no’ on this one. “Last seen” and “currently online” indicators create major user privacy issues.
Well whoever doesn’t want to use it can simply turn it off. Alternatively, Signal can come with the function disabled so it will be private by default - and anyone who wants to use it can enable it.

posts.name: mls
posts.cooked: Please read what the contributing guidelines say about options: Signal-Android/CONTRIBUTING.md at main · signalapp/Signal-Android · GitHub

Thanks for that.
It says basically “no more user options”. Surely there are some options that are basic enough for Signal to be able to consider having? “Last seen” is not a “power user” option.
In addition, we’ve spent so much time and effort discussing colour schemes, an aesthetic option which is indeed presented as an option to the user - isn’t it logical we should also be able to discuss basic functional options such as this one?

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
similar request:
https://community.signalusers.org/t/ability-to-see-if-people-are-online/5218/11

DonDino:

I would like to have some indication to know whether the current contact is still using Signal or hasn’t opened it in a long time (and so is likely to not be using it any more).

the quoted sentence sums up the the essence of this feature request. I argue this is essentially an intrusion of privacy. It is simply not your business if someone has used Signal recently. Such feature would violate privacy, and its use case is purely your curiosity.

  • You can deduce if someone has received your message using delivery indicators.
  • Whether someone has seen it is covered by read status indicators.
  • When exactly that person has read it could be added to read indicators. This is an existing feature request! Expose (delivery and) read receipt times in all conversations
  • But when someone has been using Signal in general, that is non of your business.

link_counts.title: Ability to see if people are online
Expose (delivery and) read receipt times in all conversations

posts.cooked:
Meteor0id:

But when someone has been using Signal in general, that is non of your business

You could hide your “last seen” status if you wish, but I would beg to differ - for example, if I am abroad in a country/place without access to data, and someone sends me an important message on Signal, I would very much like them to know that I haven’t been on Signal for several days/weeks - this will clue them in that I may not have data access and get them to send me an SMS or find another way to contact me rather than keep waiting for that received indicator to light up. So in some cases I would indeed want to make it others’ business ;-)

DonDino:

You could hide your “last seen” status if you wish, but I would beg to differ - for example, if I am abroad in a country/place without access to data, and someone sends me an important message on Signal, I would very much like them to know that I haven’t been on Signal for several days/weeks - this will clue them in that I may not have data access and get them to send me an SMS or find another way to contact me rather than keep waiting for that received indicator to light up. So in some cases I would indeed want to make it others’ business

If Signal is your only mode of secure and private communication, then it doesn’t matter when you were last seen. If you wish to uphold the security and privacy of your comms 100% of the time, then the other person will have to wait until you get to a WiFi or until you receive the message (the second empty mark in Signal).

For OpSec sake, if you really have to, minimize response to sending unsecure SMS only telling them when you will be able to respond over Signal - no other details. Even if by email, use PGP…but that is again tied to mobile data.

Keep in mind ASASP - As Soon As Securely Possible

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
Seeing if someone has gone missing in the Jungle, or has been abducted and murdered and their phone thrown into a river, is outside the scope of Signal Private Messenger.

  • If you wish to know when a user was last in range of a cell tower, that really is not something you should be able to figure out.
  • If you have send them an important message and need to know if they received it, look at the delivery status indicators.
  • If you need to know if they have read it, ask them to turn on read receipts.
  • If you want them to know you won’t be having reception for the coming 5 days: The ability to set an away status / message (I think this is the feature you are looking for)
  • If you want to know if they read it on time: Expose (delivery and) read receipt times in all conversations

link_counts.title: The ability to set an away status / message
Expose (delivery and) read receipt times in all conversations

posts.cooked:
IntentionalTypo:

If Signal is your only mode of secure and private communication,

But it’s not. In the real world of most people who are not political activists in danger of being murdered, we do use other means of communication. If Signal (or WA or whatever) fails, my friend is going to SMS me or PSTN-call me. And that’s normal and fine. We do prefer Signal for the most secure communications possible, but being able to be reached and communicating is, in my and I believe tons of other people’s model, even more important.

DonDino:

In the real world of most people who are not political activists in danger of being murdered, we do use other means of communication.

This is dangerous line of thinking. Opsec in your life is very much important. Everyone should have the capability and resources available to live securely like the “top dogs”. Also, everyone should be from their early ages taught that Right to Privacy is alpha and the omega of living.

It allows you freedom, it allows you planning, it allows you security and to a society as a whole it allows responding to a tyrannical regime for example, it allows for market competition.

As soon as you start slipping and making excuses, you’re slowly but surely giving way to Social Credit System aka Golden Cage.

The Devil will tempt you giving up your liberties through violent fearmongerers, pedos, drugdealers, etc.

But as people, we must be strong and not give in. Today, there’s enough tech to catch such people without relinquishing our liberties and giving way to mass surveillance.

I can understand what you’re saying, and I agree to some extent, but I believe the previous comment by @DonDino sheds light on an important point that we need to consider and plan around, viz., that Signal is not always reliable.

Not to say that it is unreliable (though my personal experience with it over the past two years suggests so), but there are times that it fails in some way or for some reason but at a time where communication with another party is still urgent or necessary. I believe in privacy, but there is only so much one can sacrifice convenience before having to sacrifice communication as well.

If Signal were as reliable to me as Android Messages has been, I would have no question of using it and encouraging all my contacts to do the same. As it stands, my contacts and I have random hangs and failings at times where the need to get a message or video call across was unfortunately FAR more important than the degree of privacy with which it was transmitted. Doesn’t always happen, but we can’t pretend it doesn’t ever happen.

anon56277322:

If Signal were as reliable to me as Android Messages has been, I would have no question of using it and encouraging all my contacts to do the same.

You are aware that Android Messages is plain ol’ SMS (or beautified insecure SMS/MMS aka RCS)?

So…it is not unusual that Android Messages are reliable. SMS will basically always work where there is cell reception without lag. Signal will work always, sometimes with no lag, sometimes (rare occasions) with a bit higher lag.

Just keep this in mind when you are sending pics / videos that you REALLY have to get across in that instant through anything other than Signal (or encrypted email). And properly trim the information you share over insecure lines.

anon56277322:

there are times that it fails in some way or for some reason but at a time where communication with another party is still urgent or necessary.

Exactly. And to clarify my own argument, I didn’t mean to say that Signal in particular is unreliable or that it alone might fail. I meant it in the sense that it does happen that sometimes one is found in a location without any data whatsoever. Networks around the world are still not 100% packet-based (very, very far from it), so GSM-based service remains a very important part. And even if there is data service, in many parts of the world this may be 2G, or even 4G but so congested that bandwidth is very limited and cannot support VoIP calls.
In those scenarios, when communication still has to happen somehow, SMS and PSTN voice calls will happen.
And of course let’s not forget that outside personal communication with friends and family, encrypted messaging is basically non-existent. If I have to call the doctor or hospital, which will obviously involve sharing lots of very private information (much more private and confidential than I share with my friends and family, by the way), do I have an encrypted option? Not a chance, just plain old PSTN routed to a landline (which may or may not run on a VoIP system). Encrypted messaging has been around for over 10 years now I believe - and business adoption is still at a less than infant stage. At this pace, it may be another 50 years before we have organisations and businesses regularly using encrypted communications options. Am I not supposed to call the hospital any more until they adopt Signal or a similar tech?

DonDino:

If I have to call the doctor or hospital, which will obviously involve sharing lots of very private information (much more private and confidential than I share with my friends and family, by the way), do I have an encrypted option?

It is a bit weird and inconsistent that they require all sorts of encryption and protective measures for emails, but nothing for voice calls.

DonDino:

Encrypted messaging has been around for over 10 years now I believe - and business adoption is still at a less than infant stage. At this pace, it may be another 50 years before we have organisations and businesses regularly using encrypted communications options.

We need a law that mandates businesses to use encrypted communications with their customers. The timing is just right for this to happen and push forward.

posts.name: Nestor Fernandes
posts.cooked:
IntentionalTypo:

Keep in mind ASASP - As Soon As Securely Possible

This is a very interesting subject. The question of keeping private information from being published in any way must be a personal choice of the user. If I tell the app that I want my “last seen” info published to my contacts, I’m using my right to waive any private information about myself to others. I don’t need a piece of code telling me what I can or cannot show.

My vote is to have the option to show the “last seen” info. It may start disabled and then require some sort of validation to start working, but I must have the final decision about what private information I want to serve.

If someone doesn’t want to let other people know when he was last online, it is his right to forbid the app to spread the info.

This is not a security breach in any way, it’s a decision of the owner of the information instead.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
NCFBR:

I’m using my right to waive any private information about myself to others. I don’t need a piece of code telling me what I can or cannot show.

That is a fallacy: I'm entitled to my opinion - Wikipedia

To assert the existence of the right is a failure to assert any justification for the opinion. Such an assertion, however, can also be an assertion of one’s own freedom or of a refusal to participate in the system of logic at hand.

The reason I point this out to you is that it starts a dangerous line of thinking. A line of thinking where there is no community with standards, but only people with their own rights and choices.

The decicion to add or not to add last seen indicators, even if optional, isn’t just about individuals making a choise for themselves. It is also about setting community standards. Signal is set up to support and promote a private style of communication. Last seen indicators inherently violate privacy. Even if you as a user don’t care about keeping that information private, the community that Signal is promoting is one where keeping status on each other does not fot in.

In practice, giving users the option to waive privacy in favor of conveignience will likely lead to many users waiving their privacy sooner or later. You might think that is their own choice, but it is the community which protects people against their own biases. Signal does have a role to protect users against their own choices.

Part of Signal is to challenge its users to only communicate in ways which don’t put your privscy at considerable risk. It edicates users by demonstrating the possibility of private messaging.

What Signal offers is private messaging without even the seduction of giving up your privacy. Adding such a feature as a last seen indicator would add in such seduction to give in to conveignience.

link_counts.title: I'm entitled to my opinion - Wikipedia

posts.name: Nestor Fernandes
posts.cooked:
Meteor0id:

The reason I point this out to you is that it starts a dangerous line of thinking. A line of thinking where there is no community with standards, but only people with their own rights and choices.

First of all, thank you for your thoughts about my comment.

The way you explained that I don’t have the right to waive my own information where I think it fits is a bit dangerous, to say the least. I’ve seen that explanation associated with ideas of socialism and comunism, where a bunch of people set the rules that all members must follow without questioning. They say that the common people does not have brains enough to know what is good or bad for themselves, so a special commitee must be created to rule them.

If you say that Signal is made that way and if I don’t like it the door is open for me to leave is one thing. I totally accept that. But I have the right to decide what information about myself I would like to publish. If the Signal program allows me to have this discretion, the responsibility is entirely mine if I use such option.

I said that this thread is interesting, and it really is. The arguments about how to know if someone is still alive are quite good: if I send a message and the read receipt is enabled, I can see that the other party is still using the Signal. There is an option in Signal to enable/disable that indication. The user decides if he wants to show that he opened the message or not.

We have two possible indications that carry bits of information about the other party:

  1. the read receipt. Is it really necessary? If the other party is interested on what you sent to him, he would reply with “Ok” or something like it. But you have the option to let the sender know if and when you opened the message. If the recipient doesn’t want to inform that the message was opened (not read, but opened), he can disable that feature at will. Sometimes letting the sender know that you opened the message and did not have the decency to reply is worse.

  2. the “last seen” indicator. Well, we don’t have it in Signal, yet. The “last seen” indicator is not different from the “read receipt” in terms of information the user wants to publish. What’s the difference between “read receipt” and “last seen” info? Both would show the timestamp of some action made by the other party. The only difference is that “read receipt” is sent to a single person or group, and the “last seen” seems to be a global information. But why one of them is accepted - with option to enable/disable - and the other cannot be accepted?

Could you please enlighten me about how my privacy could be compromised by such bit of information being published with my express consent? I really would appreciate if you could elaborate more on this.

Thank you.
